ai-mn127:1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
ai-mn127:2.1_0: And then the master builder Pañcakaṅga addressed a man,
ai-mn127:2.2_1: and after approaching he worshipped Venerable Anuruddha’s feet in my name,
ai-mn127:2.3_0: ‘Sir, the master builder Pañcakaṅga bows with his head to your feet.’
ai-mn127:2.5_0: might please accept tomorrow’s meal from Pañcakaṅga together with the mendicant Saṅgha.
ai-mn127:2.6_0: And ask whether he might please come earlier than usual,
ai-mn127:2.7_0: for Pañcakaṅga has many duties, and much work to do for the king.”
ai-mn127:2.8_1: and after approaching and worshipping venerable Anuruddha, he sat down on one side.
ai-mn127:2.8_2: He did as the nun asked.
ai-mn127:2.9_0: “Sir, the master builder Pañcakaṅga bows with his head to your feet. And then say:
ai-mn127:2.10_0: might please accept tomorrow’s meal from Pañcakaṅga together with the mendicant Saṅgha.
ai-mn127:2.11_0: And ask whether he might please come earlier than usual,
ai-mn127:2.12_0: for Pañcakaṅga has many duties, and much work to do for the king.”
ai-mn127:3.1_0: Then when the night had passed, Anuruddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went to Pañcakaṅga’s home.
ai-mn127:3.1_1: and after going, he sat down on the prepared seat.
ai-mn127:3.2_0: Then Pañcakaṅga served and satisfied Anuruddha with his own hands with a variety of delicious foods.
ai-mn127:3.3_0: When Anuruddha had eaten and washed his hands and bowl, Pañcakaṅga took a low seat, sat to one side,
ai-mn127:3.4_0: He bowed, sat down to one side, and asked Anuruddha,
ai-mn127:4.1_0: “Sir, some senior mendicants have come to me and said,
ai-mn127:4.2_0: ‘Householder, develop the limitless release of heart.’
ai-mn127:4.4_0: ‘Householder, develop the expansive release of heart.’
ai-mn127:4.5_0: Now, the limitless release of the heart and the expansive release of the heart:
ai-mn127:4.6_0: do these things differ in both meaning and phrasing? Or do they mean the same thing, and differ only in the phrasing?”
ai-mn127:5.3_0: The limitless release of the heart and the expansive release of the heart mean the same thing, and differ only in the phrasing.”
ai-mn127:6.1_0: “Householder, the limitless release of the heart and the expansive release of the heart, and these things differ in both meaning and phrasing.
ai-mn127:6.2_0: This is a way to understand how these things differ in both meaning and phrasing.
ai-mn127:7.1_0: And what is the limitless release of the heart?
ai-mn127:7.2_0: Firstly, a monk meditates spreading a heart full of love to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth.
ai-mn127:7.2_1: In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of love to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.
ai-mn127:7.5_0: equanimity to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth.
ai-mn127:7.5_1: In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of equanimity to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.
ai-mn127:7.6_0: This is called the limitless release of the heart.
ai-mn127:8.1_0: And what is the expansive release of the heart?
ai-mn127:8.2_0: It’s when a mendicant meditates determined on pervading the extent of a single tree root as expansive.
ai-mn127:8.3_0: This is called the expansive release of the heart.
ai-mn127:8.4_0: Also, a mendicant meditates determined on pervading the extent of two or three tree roots ...
ai-mn127:8.5_0: This too is called the expansive release of the heart.
ai-mn127:8.7_0: This too is called the expansive release of the heart.
ai-mn127:8.9_0: This too is called the expansive release of the heart.
ai-mn127:8.11_0: This too is called the expansive release of the heart.
ai-mn127:8.13_0: This too is called the expansive release of the heart.
ai-mn127:8.15_0: This too is called the expansive release of the heart.
ai-mn127:8.16_0: This is a way to understand how these things differ in both meaning and phrasing.
ai-mn127:9.1_0: Householder, there are these four kinds of rebirth in a future life.
ai-mn127:9.3_0: Take someone who meditates determined on pervading ‘limited radiance’.
ai-mn127:9.4_0: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in the company of the Gods of Limited Radiance.
ai-mn127:9.5_0: Next, take someone who meditates determined on pervading ‘limitless radiance’.
ai-mn127:9.6_0: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in the company of the gods of limitless radiance.
ai-mn127:9.7_0: Next, take someone who meditates determined on pervading ‘corrupted radiance’.
ai-mn127:9.8_0: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in the company of the gods of streaming radiance.
ai-mn127:9.9_0: Next, take someone who meditates determined on pervading ‘pure radiance’.
ai-mn127:9.10_0: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in the company of the gods of pure radiance.
ai-mn127:9.11_0: These are the four kinds of rebirth in a future life.
ai-mn127:10.1_0: There comes a time, householder, when the deities gather together as one. When they do so, a difference in their color is evident, but not in their radiance.
ai-mn127:10.2_0: It’s like when a person brings several oil lamps into one house.
ai-mn127:10.3_0: You can detect a difference in their flames, but not in their radiance.
ai-mn127:10.4_0: In the same way, there comes a time when the deities gather together as one. When they do so, a difference in their color is evident, but not in their radiance.
ai-mn127:11.1_0: There comes a time when those deities go their separate ways. When they do so, a difference both in their color and also in their radiance is evident.
ai-mn127:11.2_0: It’s like when a person takes those several oil lamps out of that house.
ai-mn127:11.3_0: You can detect a difference both in their flames and also in their radiance.
ai-mn127:11.4_0: In the same way, when those deities go their separate ways. When they do so, a difference both in their color and also in their radiance is evident.
ai-mn127:12.1_0: It’s not that those deities think,
ai-mn127:12.2_0: ‘What we have is permanent, lasting, and eternal.’ Rather, wherever those deities cling, that’s where they take pleasure.
ai-mn127:12.3_0: It’s like when flies are being carried along on a carrying-pole or basket. It’s not that they think,
ai-mn127:12.4_0: ‘What we have is permanent, lasting, and eternal.’ Rather, wherever those flies cling, that’s where they take pleasure.
ai-mn127:12.5_0: In the same way, those deities don’t think,
ai-mn127:12.6_0: ‘What we have is permanent, lasting, and eternal.’ Rather, wherever those deities cling, that’s where they take pleasure.”
ai-mn127:13.1_0: When he had spoken, Venerable Abhiya Kaccāna said to Venerable Anuruddha:
ai-mn127:13.3_0: But I have something to ask about it.
ai-mn127:13.4_0: Do all the radiant deities have limited radiance, or do some there have limitless radiance?”
ai-mn127:13.5_0: “In that case, Reverend Kaccāna, there are some of the deities that have limited radiance.”
ai-mn127:14.1_0: “What is the cause, Venerable Anuruddha, what is the reason why, when those deities have been reborn in a single order of gods, some deities there have limited radiance, while some have limitless radiance?”
ai-mn127:14.2_0: “Well then, Reverend Kaccāna, I’ll ask you about this in return, and you can answer as you like.
ai-mn127:14.3_0: What do you think, Reverend Kaccāna?
ai-mn127:14.4_0: Which of these two kinds of mental development is more expansive: when a mendicant meditates determined on pervading as expansive the extent of a single tree root, or two or three tree roots?”
ai-mn127:14.5_0: Which one of these two ways of developing the mind, what is the development of the mind?”
ai-mn127:14.6_0: “When a mendicant meditates on two or three tree roots.”
ai-mn127:14.7_0: This is the way of developing this mind, a great hermit, who has gone to development.”
ai-mn127:14.9_0: Which of these two kinds of mental development is more expansive: when a mendicant meditates determined on pervading as expansive the extent of two or three tree roots, or a single village district ...
ai-mn127:14.10_0: Which one of these two ways of developing the mind, what is the development of the mind?”
ai-mn127:14.11_0: “When a mendicant meditates determined on pervading as far as the village district,
ai-mn127:14.12_0: This is the way of developing this mind, a great hermit, who has gone to development.”
ai-mn127:14.14_0: Which one of these two ways of developing the mind, what is the development of the mind?”
ai-mn127:14.15_0: “When a mendicant meditates on two or three village districts the extent of two or three village districts,”
ai-mn127:14.16_0: This is the way of developing this mind, a great hermit, who has gone to development.”
ai-mn127:14.18_0: Which one of these two ways of developing the mind, what is the development of the mind?”
ai-mn127:14.19_0: “When a mendicant meditates on two or three kingdoms,”
ai-mn127:14.20_0: This is the way of developing this mind, a great hermit, who has gone to development.”
ai-mn127:14.22_0: Which one of these two ways of developing the mind, what is the development of the mind?”
ai-mn127:14.23_0: “When a mendicant meditates on two or three kingdoms ...
ai-mn127:14.24_0: This is the way of developing this mind, a great hermit, who has gone to development.”
ai-mn127:14.26_0: Which one of these two ways of developing the mind, what is the development of the mind?”
ai-mn127:14.27_0: “When a mendicant meditates on this land surrounded by ocean.”
ai-mn127:14.28_0: This is the way of developing this mind, a great hermit, who has gone to development.”
ai-mn127:14.29_0: “This is the cause, Reverend Kaccāna, this is the reason why, when those deities have been reborn in a single order of gods, some deities there have limited radiance, while some have limitless radiance.”
ai-mn127:15.2_0: But I have something to ask about it.
ai-mn127:15.3_0: She’s able to have pure radiance, or do some deities have pure radiance?”
ai-mn127:15.4_0: “Reverend Kaccāna, there are some deities who have corrupted radiance, while some have pure radiance.”
ai-mn127:16.1_0: “What is the cause, Venerable Anuruddha, what is the reason why, when those deities have been reborn in a single order of gods, some deities there have corrupted radiance, while some have pure radiance?”
ai-mn127:16.2_0: “Well then, Reverend Kaccāna, I shall give you a simile.
ai-mn127:16.3_0: For by means of a simile some sensible people understand the meaning of what is said.
ai-mn127:16.4_0: Suppose an oil lamp was burning with impure oil and impure wick.
ai-mn127:16.5_0: Because of the impurity of the oil and the wick it burns dimly, as it were.
ai-mn127:16.6_0: In the same way, take some mendicant who meditates determined on pervading ‘corrupted radiance’.
ai-mn127:16.7_0: Their physical discomfort is not completely settled, their dullness and drowsiness is not completely eradicated, and their restlessness and remorse is not completely eliminated.
ai-mn127:16.8_0: Because of this they practice absorption dimly, as it were.
ai-mn127:16.9_0: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in the company of the gods of streaming radiance.
ai-mn127:16.10_0: Suppose an oil lamp was burning with pure oil and pure wick.
ai-mn127:16.11_0: Because of the purity of the oil and the wick it doesn’t burn dimly, as it were.
ai-mn127:16.12_0: In the same way, take some mendicant who meditates determined on pervading ‘pure radiance’.
ai-mn127:16.13_0: Their physical discomfort is completely settled, their dullness and drowsiness is completely eradicated, and their restlessness and remorse is completely eliminated.
ai-mn127:16.14_0: Because of this they don’t practice absorption dimly, as it were.
ai-mn127:16.15_0: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in the company of the gods of pure radiance.
ai-mn127:16.16_0: “This is the cause, Reverend Kaccāna, this is the reason why, when those deities have been reborn in a single order of gods, some deities there have corrupted radiance, while some have pure radiance.”
ai-mn127:17.1_0: When he had spoken, Venerable Abhiya Kaccāna said to Venerable Anuruddha:
ai-mn127:17.4_0: ‘So I have heard’ or ‘It ought to be like this.’
ai-mn127:17.5_0: Rather, you say: ‘These deities are like this, those deities are like that.’
ai-mn127:17.7_0: ‘Clearly, Venerable Anuruddha has previously lived together with those deities, conversed, and engaged in discussion.’”
ai-mn127:17.8_0: “Your words are clearly invasive and intrusive, Reverend Kaccāna.
ai-mn127:17.10_0: For a long time I have previously lived together with those deities, conversed, and engaged in discussion.”
ai-mn127:18.1_0: When he had spoken, Venerable Abhiya Kaccāna said to Pañcakaṅga the master builder,
ai-mn127:18.3_0: to have given up your state of uncertainty, and to have got the chance to listen to this exposition of the teaching.”
ai-mn127:18.4_0: The seventh sub-chapter on Anuruddha is finished.
